title: Jan Hendrik Scholten
text:
Jan Hendrik Scholten (born Johannes Heinrich Scholten, 17 August 1811, <a href="Vleuten">Vleuten</a> – 10 April 1885, <a href="Leiden">Leiden</a>), <a href="Netherlands">Dutch</a> <a href="Protestant">Protestant</a> theologian, was born at <a href="Vleuten">Vleuten</a> near <a href="Utrecht%20%28city%29">Utrecht</a>.
Biography.
After studying at <a href="Utrecht%20University">Utrecht University</a>, he was appointed professor of theology in 1840 at <a href="Franeker">Franeker</a>. From Franeker in 1843 he went to Leiden as professor "extraordinarius", and in 1845 was promoted to the rank of "ordinarius". Through Scholten, <a href="Abraham%20Kuenen">Abraham Kuenen</a> became interested in theology; Scholten was not then the radical theologian he became later. The two scholars in course of time created a movement resembling that of the <a href="university%20of%20T%C3%BCbingen">Tübingen</a> School in Germany. From his theology there "began to rise a different type of spirit, the spirit of absolute <a href="antisupernaturalism">antisupernaturalism</a> of the German idealistic kind."
Pursuing first the study of dogmatic theology and the philosophy of religion, Scholten published a work on the "Principles of the Theology of the Reformed Church" (2 vols, 1848–1850, 4th ed. 1861–1862). He then gave special attention to the <a href="New%20Testament">New Testament</a>, and wrote "A Critical Study of the Gospel of John" (1864, in German 1867).
Scholten's other works include:
An account of his theological development is given in "Afscheidsrede bij het Neerleggen van het Hoogleeraarsambt" (1881), and in the biography written by A Kuenen, "Levensbericht van J. Henricus Scholten" (1885).
He became member of the <a href="Royal%20Netherlands%20Academy%20of%20Arts%20and%20Sciences">Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences</a> in 1856.
